cost_options.label: Surface-Applied Rubber Tread with Adhesive
cost_options.notes: Materials: $80-$150 (rubber tread and adhesive). Labor: 1.5-2 hours per tread x $56.65/hour = $85 - $115. Total: $165-$265 per tread.

cost_options.label: Cast-in-Place Composite Tread with Tactile Domes
cost_options.notes: Materials: $200-$350 (composite tread with integrated tactile domes). Labor: 2.5-3.5 hours per tread x $56.65/hour = $140-$200. Total: $340-$550 per tread. High durability for heavy traffic.

cost_options.label: Retrofit Rubber Stair Nosing with Contrast Strip
cost_options.notes: Materials: $40-$70 (rubber nosing). Labor: 1-1.75 hours per tread x $56.65/hour = $57-$100. Total: $97-$170.

material_options.properties: Slip-resistant, high color contrast, flexible, good for retrofit applications, requires regular cleaning
Extreme Durability, long design life, suitable for high traffic areas, may require professional installation
Good for retrofit solution, flexible, can handle thermal expansion, may be less durable than full tread replacements

maintenance.notes: Dust mop with microfiber to remove dirt and soil. Critical for maintaining slip resistance and appearance.
Clean with auto scrubber and pH-neutral cleaner. Dilute cleaner per manufacturer's instructions. Avoid strong chemicals.
Adjust cleaning protocol based on weather conditions (e.g., increased cleaning in winter to remove salt and debris).

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Mandates accessibility standards for the built environment in Ontario, including requirements for tactile walking surface indicators (TWSIs) and stair nosings.

compliance.regulation: Canadian National Institute for the Blind (CNIB) Guidelines
compliance.notes: CNIB guidelines provide recommendations for TWSIs, color contrast, and stair nosing design to enhance safety for visually impaired individuals.
Specifies requirements for tactile attention indicators at the top of stairs (one tread depth back from the edge) and for slip-resistant surfaces on ramps and stairs.

cost_options.label: Durable Paint (Professional)
cost_options.notes: Professional application of durable, high-contrast paint to stair edges. Materials (paint, primer, tape): $50. Labor (8 hours at $50/hr): $400, Total Cost: $450-$500 (Based on stairway of ~12 steps)

cost_options.label: Durable Paint (DIY)
cost_options.notes: DIY application. Includes paint, primer, painter's tape and basic tools. Estimates does not include personal time.

cost_options.label: Non-Slip Tape (Professional Installation)
cost_options.notes: Professional installation of non-slip, high-contrast tape strips. Material: $60 (Tape - LifeGrip) Labor: 5 hours. (Includes prep work and install. Installation at $56.65/hr) Total ~$316.65.

cost_options.label: Non-Slip Tape (DIY Installation)
cost_options.notes: DIY installation using pre-cut, non-slip high contrast tape strips. (e.g LifeGrip ). Material: ~$60, 0 labor

material_options.properties: Long-lasting, easy to clean, available in high-contrast colors, requires primer for best adhesion.
Provides added traction, reducing slip hazards, higher cost, available in limited colors.
Durable, water-resistant, easy to install, available with reflective or glow-in-the-dark stripe for improved visibility in low light.
Strong adhesive, withstands heavy foot traffic, suitable for indoor/outdoor use, may require careful installation to avoid air bubbles.

maintenance.notes: Inspect paint for chips, cracks, or wear. Touch up as needed to maintain high-contrast and prevent slipping. Consider anti-slip reapplication every 1-2 years depending on wear.
Clean painted surfaces with a mild detergent and water to remove dirt and debris.
Inspect tape for peeling, wear, or damage. Replace damaged strips immediately to maintain safety and contrast.
Clean tape strips regularly to maintain traction and visibility.

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Requires contrasting marking (minimum 50mm wide) on top of stair nosing.
Specifies minimum run for stairs (280mm) and maximum rise (180mm). Addresses tread and riser requirements, restricting open stair risers.
Requires exit stairs to be designed and constructed as a fire separation with a minimum 1-hour fire-resistance rating if more than 3 stories are connected.
Although not legally binding, CNIB guidelines recommend high contrast between surfaces to improve visibility for individuals with low vision.

cost_options.label: Basic Handrail Extension (Non-Slip Grip)
cost_options.notes: Includes materials (non-slip grip extension): $75, Labor (3.5 hours): $200. Varies by length and complexity.

cost_options.label: Mid-Range Handrail Extension (Contoured Non-Slip)
cost_options.notes: Includes contoured non-slip material: $135, Labor (6.75 hours): $380. More ergonomic design.

cost_options.label: Premium Handrail Extension (Textured Composite)
cost_options.notes: Includes high-end textured composite: $215, Labor (10 hours): $566.50. Increased durability and grip.

material_options.properties: Durable, weather-resistant, excellent grip, various colors.
Comfortable grip, good for indoor applications, easy to clean.
High friction, chemical resistance, suitable for public spaces.

maintenance.notes: Clean with a damp cloth and mild detergent; inspect for damage.
Check for wear and tear, clean more frequently in polluted or coastal areas.
Clean escalator handrails to maintain motion indicator visibility using EHC Handrail Cleaner.

compliance.notes: Requires continuous graspable handrails along the entire length of stairs.

Handrails shall extend horizontally at the required height, not less than 300 mm beyond the top riser and continue to slope for a depth of one tread beyond the bottom riser followed by a 300 mm horizontal extension.
Handrail heights on stairs and ramps shall be not less than 865 mm, and not more than 965 mm.
CNIB provides resources and standards related to accessibility, including handrail design.

cost_options.label: Aluminum ADA Stair Sign

maintenance.notes: Clean signs with a mild cleaning solution and soft cloth to remove dirt and grime. Avoid abrasive or acidic cleaners.
Inspect signs for damage, fading, or wear and tear. Replace damaged or outdated signs promptly.
Repainting is essential to make your signage look fresh. Ensure you use an appropriate paint for outdoor use.

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Sets guidelines on stair design elements like treads, risers, handrails, and contrasting colors. Aims to achieve barrier-free accessibility.

compliance.regulation: Canadian National Institute for the Blind (CNIB) 'Clearing Our Path' guidelines
compliance.notes: TWSI are crucial for providing non-visual cues to individuals with visual impairments. Extends the full width of the stairs and positioned at least 6 inches from the edge of the top and bottom steps.
Requires contrasting marking (minimum 50mm wide) on top of the nosing and continuous and easy-to-grip handrails on both sides, mounted 865-925mm above tread nosings.

maintenance.notes: Routine checks for rust, mold, paint discoloration, broken hardware. Clean mold immediately. Prevents future problems.
Cleaning of dirt and debris to maintain appearance. Inspect for damage from weather or vandalism.
Professional inspection and servicing, including light replacement and touch-ups. Replace any damaged components.
Address burned-out lights promptly for illuminated signage. Repair or replace damaged signs to maintain a professional look.

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Requires organizations to identify, remove, and prevent accessibility barriers. Standards for customer service, information, employment, transportation, and public spaces.
Sets accessibility standards under AODA in five areas: customer service, information, transportation, employment and public spaces.
Covers requirements for accessible buildings, including ramps, washrooms, power door operators, and signs. Requirements for new construction and major renovations.
Barrier-free design recommendations based on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD), including braille and tactile signage.

cost_options.label: Concrete Ramp (Basic)
cost_options.notes: Materials: $1,500 - $3,500 (concrete, rebar, forms), Labor: 25-60 hours @ $56.65/hr ($1,416.25 - $3,399), Total: $2,916.25 - $6,899. Installation includes basic foundation and finishing.

cost_options.label: Asphalt Ramp (Small, Residential)
cost_options.notes: Materials: $750 - $1,750 (asphalt, gravel base), Labor: 13-31 hours @ $56.65/hr ($736.45 - $1,756.15), Total: $1,486.45 - $3,506.15. Suitable for low-traffic residential areas.

cost_options.label: Slip-Resistant Composite Ramp (Modular)

material_options.properties: Durable, long-lasting (20-40 years), requires less maintenance, high initial cost, can absorb CO2.
Cost-effective, quick installation, flexible, requires more frequent maintenance, shorter lifespan (15-20 years), sensitive to extreme temperatures.
Lightweight, modular, durable, slip-resistant surfaces, often requires less site preparation.

maintenance.notes: Sealing cracks as needed to prevent water damage and ensure slip resistance.
Sealcoating every 2-3 years to protect from weather and traffic; patching potholes as they appear.
Cleaning as needed, checking connections and anchoring points annually.

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Ensures accessibility standards are met in new construction and redevelopment, including ramp slope (max 1:12), width (minimum 900mm), and landings (1670mm x 1670mm).
Specifies technical requirements for ramps in barrier-free paths of travel, including handrail dimensions (30-40mm diameter, 865-965mm height) and guard requirements.
Recommends a 1:12 slope for public access ramps.
Ramps must meet CNIB standards for tactile walking surface indicators at curb ramps.
